*[Bug 18702] print.data.frame does not respect na.print for missing column names*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18702>

Elin Waring (<mailto:elin.waring@gmail.com|elin.waring@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |elin.waring@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Elin Waring (<mailto:elin.waring@gmail.com|elin.waring@gmail.com>) ---
This is true. It seems like there are two issues.

 Practically, I think the first issue is that normally a character vector
prints with quotation marks, which allows differentiation of "NA" and NA.
Factors also print without quotation marks but use  <NA> to print NA values.
For both character and factor vectors na.print also works as expected. For
matrices the column names that are NA are printed as <NA>.

  However the data frame print method does not put quotation marks around the
column names and does not print the NA as <NA>. Hence you cannot distinguish
names(df) values of "NA" and NA. 

The second issue is that  print.data.frame() also does not respect the na.print
option. Its signature does not include it, and, therefore, it is not passed to
the print.default after the data frame is coerced to a matrix. 



That said, there is a question in my mind about whether if there was a na.print
option for data frames if it should apply to the data, to the names, or to
both. For named vectors and matrices it applies to both, so that would be
consistent.
